column2: §gWhite Mountains§!\n\nAlso known as the Ered Nimrais, meaning 'Mountains of the White Horns', the snow-capped mountain range reaches from the tip of Andrast in the West to the height of the Mindolluin in the East and makes up a impenetrable barrier between the populated parts of Gondor and the Lands of Calenardhon to the North. Many of Gondors and Rohans freshwater streams originate in the fringes of these peaks to flow into the Sea of Belegaer or become a tributary of the Great River Anduin

§gMarshes of the Anduin§!\n\nAlong the shores of the Great River there are many marshes. These marshes make movement and civilization difficult, and are generally avoided except by outlaws and those hunting said outlaws.

§gPlains of Anórien§!\n\nFounded in the year 3320 of the Second Age, Anórien, meaning 'Land of the Sun' is a temperate region laying between the White Mountains to the South, the Mering Stream to the West and the Entwash to the North. Its boundaries reach the Great River Anduin to the East. Fertile farmlands and soft woodlands stretch the land and it experienced settlement by men as early as the Elder Days. Some of the greatest works of Númenórean architecture ever seen, such as Minas Tirith and Osgiliath, are located here.

§gOsgiliath§!\n\nThe city also known as the 'Citadel of the Stars' was founded at the End of the Second Era by Anárion and Isildur at both shore banks of the Anduin and lies halfway between Minas Tirith and Minas Ithil. The city halves are connected via a great bridge that was expanded and enlargened over time as well as support for the Dome of the Stars housing the Osgiliath Palantíri. Some time after its founding it was designated as capital of the Kingdom of Gondor and Royal seat of kings, who would reign from the Great Hall. The decline of the city began, when the city was sacked during the Kin-strife year 1437 of the Third Age and years later the Great Plague 1636 TA marking the slow depopulation and eventual abandonment in 2475 TA after being overrun.

§gDrúadan Forest§!\n\nThe small pine forest located in Southeast Anórien grew around the beacon-hill of Eilenach and is named after the indigenous inhabitants of wild-men. The Great Road straddles the Northern Outskirts of these woods and a small forgotten pathway leads through the southern part of it.

§gCair Andros§!\n\nA large narrow ship-shaped river island located in the middle of the Anduin holds a very important strategic position for whoever attempts to hold the banks of the Great River. At the northern tip the island ends in sharp rocks, that split the water like the bow of a ship creating the foam that serves as the namegiver of 'Ship of Long-foam'. During the Third Age fortications have been erected there that at some point were abandoned again.

§gMinas Tirith§!\n\nOriginally founded by the name of Minas Anor - 'Tower of the Sun' in 3320 of the Second Age, holds a long unbroken history as the watchful guard looming over the fields of Pelennor and as the Bastion of Gondor against the numerous threats it faces. Situated on the Hill of the Guard at the "knee" of Mount Mindolluin, it consists of seven concentric layers that have gradually been expanded upon with a outer City Wall constructed of the same indestructible black rock of the Orthanc. At the top of the city lays the Citadel and the White Tree with a more recent addition of the White Tower. In TA 1636, the capital was moved from Osgiliath to Minas Anor under reasons of defensibility and slow desolation of former. Its name translates from Sindarin as 'Tower of Guard'.

§gPelennor Fields§!\n\nOutside of the two great cities, inbetween Minas Tirith and Osgiliath lie stretches of fertile farmland and hills dotted with townships and villages and since TA 2954 surrounded by the fortification of the Rammas Echor giving the lands the name Pelennor, meaning 'fenced land'.

§gHarlond§!\n\nSome 4 to 5 miles south of the White City lies its harbour that allows for frequent waterway traffic with the Rest of Gondor and the World. It is protected by the Rammas Echor. Its name translates as 'Southern Haven'.

§gPlains of Lossarnach§!\n\nThe region directly south of Anórien, Lossarnach refers to the hills and flowery plains between the Celos and the Erui. This region is commonly visited by those living in Anórien for flower and fruit harvesting, in addition to vacations to experience the beauty. The region is so famed for its flowers, that is it named after them. Lossarnach is a mixed Sindarin-Prenúmenórean word meaning 'Flowery Arnach'.

§gImloth Melui§!\n\nMeaning 'Sweet Flower-Valley', Imloth Melui was a mountain valley tucked away in the southern foothills of the White Mountains. Known for their roses, every year people from Minas Tirith would come here to harvest the flowers.

§gTumladen§!\n\nA large valley along the road from Minas Tirith to Ethring, Tumladen holds the eastern border of Lebennin with Lossarnach. Meaning 'Wide Valley', the region is a mostly flat expanse, covering the land between the Celos and the Sirith

§gCliffside Mountains of Tolfalas§!\n\nThe island of Tolfalas stands a lone beacon among the Bay of Belfalas. The significant island in the bay, its name means 'Island of the Shore' due to the island only being beach or mountain. During the Drowning of Númenór and the coastal devastation that followed, the island was nearly destroyed, and only the mountains survived. Over the years since then, the Island has served as a military outpost for Gondor, as well as the Corsairs after the Kin-Strife, due to the strategic location within the bay.

§gHenneth Annûn§!\n\nA small cave in the woods of Ithilien, Henneth Annûn, also known as the 'Window on the West' or the 'Window on the Sunset', was a hidden outpost for the Ithilien Rangers. Created in T.A. 2901 during Turgon II's reign, this outpost remained secret and saw usage throughout the War of the Ring. It was finally abandoned when the Rangers pulled out of Ithilien to protect Osgiliath.

§gWoods of Ithilien§!

Named for the original name of Minas Morgul, Minas Ithil, Ithilien is the 'Land of the Moon', and the eastern counterpart to Anórien. Given to Isildur to rule from Minas Ithil, Ithilien has had a troubled history. During the War of the Last Alliance, the region was captured by Sauron's Orcs, but was retaken with the end of the war.

Over the Third Age, the region has seen countless invasions by the Haradrim, the Easterlings and Mordor Orcs. It has been steadily depopulating, and by T.A 2901, Gondor's illusion of control over the region was gone. By T.A 2954, the only inhabitants of the region were Mordor Orcs and the Ithilien Rangers and their descendants. Following the eruption of Mount Doom, those remaning fled the region, leaving the region nearly uncontested.

§gPelargir§!\n\nOne of the earliest Númenórean settlements in Middle Earth, Pelargir was founded in S.A. 2350 as a haven of the Faithful. Always being a port settlement, Pelargir is the greatest port and harbor in Gondor. Gondor's navy is based out of Pelargir, and the Ship Kings built grand houses in and around the city, giving the city its meaning, 'Garth of Royal Ships'.

§gFarmlands of Lebennin§!\n\nKnown for the Five Rivers of Lebennin, the Anduin, the Celos, the Sirith, the Serni and the Gilrain, Lebennin literally means 'Five Rivers'. These waterways dominate the region and define its borders. Behind Anórien, it is the most populous region of Gondor, and holds the largest port in the realm, Pelargir.

§gPlains of Lamedon§!\n\nBordered by the Morthond to the West, the White Mountains to the North and the Gilrain to the East, Lamedon is a land of river valleys and mountain foothills. One of the defining natural landmarks is the Tarlang mountains, which local legends say are the remains of a fallen Giant. It is a sparsely populated region, with the only major settlements, Calembel and Ethring, being centered along natural river crossings. Lamedon is a pre-Númenorean name with no known translation.

§gHills of Tarnost§!\n\nBordered by the Morthond to the West, the White Mountains to the North and the Gilrain to the East, Lamedon is a land of river valleys and mountain foothills. One of the defining natural landmarks is the Tarlang mountains, which local legends say are the remains of a fallen Giant. §gEthring§!\n\nA small market town on the crossings of the Ringló, Ethring is the center of trade for much of eastern Lamedon. Its location on the only major crossing of the Ringló additionally makes the town strategically important to the region. It is named for the river crossing, roughly translating to "cold crossing".
§gCalembel§!\n\nThe capital of Lamedon, Calembel is a town located on a small hill near the crossing of river Ciril. Its name translates to "Green Fence". Ironically enough, Calembel has no walls.

§gPlains of Morthond Vale§!

The Morthond Vale, otherwise known as the Blackroot Vale, is the river valley around the Morthond River. The region is directly south of the Paths of the Dead, and is rumored to be haunted by Oathbreakers.

The region also holds cultural significance for Gondorians. The Black Stone of Erech was brought to Gondor by Isildur, and it was here where the Oathbreakers swore an oath to come to Gondor's aid should they be called.

§gMountains of Tarlang§!\n\nA southern spur of the White Mountains, the mountains of Tarlang are rumored to be the body of a Giant. Long in the past, the Giant Tarlang, who was carrying a large bag of stones, tripped and broke his neck. The other Giants did not move his body, so it was incorportad into the land. His head became the nothernmost peak, his neck the pass through the mountains, and the stones he was carrying the two southern peaks.

§gErech§!

Erech is the Daen name given to the hill where the Stone of Erech lies. The name eventually came to represent the entire area around the Stone

The area was once heavily populated by Daen tribes. These men once swore an oath to Isildur, and upon breaking that oath, became the Oathbreakers. Despite now residing in the Paths of the Dead, they are still rumored to occasionally return to their homelands around Erech.

§gPlains of Anfalas§!\n\nAnfalas, otherwise known as Langstrand, is the coastal region between the Lefnui and the Morthond, south of the Pinnath Gelin. The region, being a long shore, and literally translating to "Long Shore", has been plagued by corsair invasions and raids.

§gHills of Pinnath Gelin§!\n\nPinnath Gelin, translated as "Green Hills" is a rolling highland between the southern slopes of the White Mountains and the shores of Anfalas. While technically a fiefdom at some points in Gondor's history, it generally is regarded as part of the Fiefdom of Anfalas.

§gPlains of Pinnath Gelin§!\n\nPinnath Gelin, translated as "Green Hills" is a rolling highland between the southern slopes of the White Mountains and the shores of Anfalas. While technically a fiefdom at some points in Gondor's history, it generally is regarded as part of the Fiefdom of Anfalas. The land is not too arable, and it predominantely used as a grazing ground for cattle, horses and sheep.

§gWoods of Pinnath Gelin§!\n\nPinnath Gelin, translated as "Green Hills" is a rolling highland between the southern slopes of the White Mountains and the shores of Anfalas. While technically a fiefdom at some points in Gondor's history, it generally is regarded as part of the Fiefdom of Anfalas.

§gPlains of Andrast§!\n\nAt the far reaches of Gondor, the White Mountains arc south, protruding the Sea of Belegaer by the cape of Andrast, literally meaning "Long Cape". Otherwise known as Ras Morthil, "Dark-horn Cape", the region is mostly forest and foothills of the White Mountains.

§gCirith Aralanthir§!\n\nA small mountain pass at the base of the Andrast peninsula, Cirith Aralanthir is one of two passes through the southern arc of the White Mountains. Translated as "Pass of the Royal Waterfall", the pass is known for a series of small waterfalls.

§gPlains of Druwaith Iaur§!\n\nDrúwaith Iaur, also known as Old Púkel Land, is a large plain north of the White Mountains on the western expanse of Gondor. This region was the original home of the Drúedain, who were dispersed by the original Númenórean scouts and settlers.

§gHills of Belfalas§!

The land of Belfalas is a hilly and mountainous expanse between the Gilrain and Ringló rivers. In the center of the region lies the Ered Tarthonion, a southern spur of the White Mountains.

This region was one of the first colonized by Númenórean settlers, and is still relatively densely populated today. Belfalas is also called Dor-en-Ernil, in reference to the ruler of the land, the Prince of Dol Amroth.

§gEred Tarthonion§!\n\nEred Tarthonion, Sindarin for "Mountains of the Lofty Pines", is a southern arm of the White Mountains, with its foothills covering most of the region of Belfalas. There is only one major pass through these mountains, the Cirith Dudhrandir.

§gDol Amroth§!\n\nDol Amroth is the most important city in Belfalas. Originally settled by Elves in the late First Age, they founded the port and the Tirith Aear, the Sea-ward Tower. Elves continued to move to the area throughout the Second and beginning of the Third Age. In the middle of the Second Age, Númenórean colonists began to settle the region. In TA 1981, King Amroth, the former King of Lórien was lost in the nearby waters, and the region officially began to be known as Dol Amroth, in honor of the fallen king.

§gNan Rochben§!\n\nNan Rochben, Sindarin for "Knightly Vale", is a sparsely populated upland vale within the Ered Tarthonion. The land is not very arable, and instead, is used as great sheperding grounds.

§gEdhellond§!\n\nEdhellond, the "Elf-Haven", is one of the oldest settlements in Gondor. It was founded by Sindar, fleeing the destruction of Morgoth in Beleriand. As time passed, more Elves moved to the region, and in SA 1697, ships began leaving for Valinor. By the end of the Third Age, almost all Elves had left, with only a small handful left to maintain the settlement.

§gSteppes of Harondor§!\n\nHarondor, also known as "South Gondor", is the land between the Poros to the north, the Harnen to the south, the Ephel Dúath to the east, and the Bay of Belfalas to the west. The region is predominately a steppe, with some plains surrounding the highlands. The ownership of the land has been heavily contested, at some times controlled by Gondor, and at others, controlled by various Haradrim tribes, or even the Corsairs of Umbar.

§gPlains of Harondor§!\n\nHarondor, also known as "South Gondor", was the land between the Poros to the north, the Harnen to the south, the Ephel Dúath to the east, and the Bay of Belfalas to the west. The region is predominately a steppe, with some plains surrounding the highlands. The ownership of the land has been heavily contested, at some times controlled by Gondor, and at others, controlled by various Haradrim tribes, or even the Corsairs of Umbar.

§gBarad Harn§!\n\nBarad Harn, the Tower of the South, was one of the original Númenórean settlements in Harondor. Over the years, it has served as a major military outpost for Gondor, the Haradrim and the Corsairs.

§gGobel Mirlond§!\n\nThe "Jewel-haven Town", Gobel Mirlond was the largest settlement between Umbar and Pelargir. While under Gondorian control, the settlement has served as the capital of the Harondor fiefdom. Like many of the other coastal settlements, Gobel Mirlond was originally a Númenórean colony settled during the Second Age.

§gDale§!

Dale is a prosperous city situated in a picturesque valley, known for its rich history and vibrant trade. Located at the foot of the Lonely Mountain, it was once a bustling hub of commerce and culture.

When Smaug descended upon Erebor, Dale was destroyed. Since Bard slew the Dragon, he and some of the people of Lake-Town have resettled the city, bringing commerce back to the region.

§gEsgaroth§!

Esgaroth, also known as Lake-town, is a unique city situated on the Long Lake. Built upon wooden platforms and connected by a network of canals, it floats upon the waters, providing a remarkable sight to behold.

Located at the confluence of the Celduin and the Forest River, the city enjoys a rich trade culture, which brings wares from all over the region.

§gPlains of Gramavuld§!\n\nThe land of Gramavuld, Sindarin for the Land of the Grammas, is an expanse of rivers, plains and rollings hills that covers the land between the Celduin to the South, the Carnen to the East, the Iron Hills and Erebor to the north, and Mirkwood to the West. The vast majority of the populace are Northmen, who enjoy a rich trade culture due to the prominent river and roads that pass through the region.

§gLong Marshes§!

The Long Marshes are a vast expanse of wetlands that stretch for miles, creating a unique and challenging terrain. This region is characterized by its marshy, waterlogged landscape, with a labyrinth of interconnecting marshes, swamps, and shallow bodies of water.

Few live here, and there are rumors of a secret evil lurking within the water.
§gMistrand§!\n\nMistrand, meaning Merged Waters to the Easterlings, is a city in Rhûn located on a bay of the same name on the Sea of Rhûn.
§gLest§!\n\nLest is a city in Rhûn located at the mouth of Othnen river where it meets the Sea of Rhûn.
§gDourband§!\n\nDourband is a city on the coast of the Sea of Rhûn. It is known for its vineyards and fruit orchards.

§gPlains of Rhûn§!\n\nRhûn is a vast land lying to the east of Rhovanion and reaching as far east as the Yellow Mountains. It is known for its endless steppes of empty grasslands and rolling hills. The men of Rhûn, also known as Easterlings, have been living in these lands since the First Age and are famous for their charioteers.

The men of Rhûn, also known as Easterlings, have been living in these lands since the First Age and are famous for their charioteers.

§gDol Guldur§!\n\nDol Guldur, Sindarin for the Hill of Sorcery, is a stronghold located on the highest point in southern Mirkwood. It was originally a Silvan elven settlement, called Amon Lane, the Naked Hill, because trees did not grow on its summit, but it was abandoned by the elves in the Second Age. In around 1000 of the Third Age, a shadow fell on Mirkwood, and Dol Guldur became the host to the Necromancer, who was ousted from Dol Guldur by Gandalf in 2063, but a dark presence lingered in Mirkwood. In 2951, the Nazgûl, Khamûl the Easterling, was sent by Sauron to Dol Guldur to rule in his stead.

§gElvenking's Halls§!\n\nThe Elvenking's Halls, also known as Felegoth, is the great underground stronghold of the Silvan elves in northern Mirkwood. It was constructed in the early 1000s of the Third Age by King Thranduil, who was inspired by Thingol's halls of Menegroth in Doriath during the First Age. The halls of the cavern are said to be brightly illuminated and has gardens with natural beauty aplenty.

§gEnchanted Vale§!\n\nThe Enchanted River flows north from the Mountains of Mirkwood, meeting the Forest River near the Halls of the Elvenking. The river, also called the Rhachló, is said to be cursed - any who touches its black waters immediately falls into a long and deep sleep.
§gGuldur Outerlands§!\n\nCorrupted by the presence of evil emanating from Dol Guldur, the region of Mirkwood surrounding the fortress has a particularly dark aura.

§gForest of Mirkwood§!\n\nMirkwood, known in Sindarin as Taur e-Ndaedelos, is a great forest in Rhovanion lying east of the River Anduin. It is a deep, thick, and dark forest home to many races and creatures criss-crossed with roads and rivers. It was once known as Greenwood the Great, or Eryn Galen, until a dark shadow fell upon it in the early 1000s of the Third Age.

§gHills of Mirkwood§!\n\nMirkwood, known in Sindarin as Taur e-Ndaedelos, is a great forest in Rhovanion lying east of the River Anduin. It is a deep, thick, and dark forest home to many races and creatures criss-crossed with roads and rivers. It was once known as Greenwood the Great, or Eryn Galen, until a dark shadow fell upon it in the early 1000s of the Third Age.
§gForest of the Woodland Realm§!\n\nThe northern most reaches of Mirkwood retain some of the splendour of the days of Greenwood, even as the rest of the forest fell into darkness.

§gWoodmen-town§!\n\nThe Woodmen are a hardy folk of Northmen who dwell on the western edges of Mirkwood. The Woodmen witnessed the transformation of Greenwood the Great into Mirkwood over the centuries and have grown into deeply superstitious people as a result.

§gBeorn's House§!\n\nAlso called Beorninghús, Beorn's Hall is a broad wooden manor house built by the great skin-changer Beorn, who famously aided the dwarves during their Quest of Erebor. The manor has a large courtyard with multiple guest wings, with a great hall in which many guests were served.

§gCaras Galadhon§!\n\nMeaning fort surrounded by bulwarks, Caras Galadhon is a fortified city built by the Silvan Elves in the 2000s T.A. to watch over the growing threat of evil in the east. Despite its foundations as a fortification, the city is beautiful, with settlements spiralling upwards on platforms amongst the trees.

§gEagles Eyrie§!\n\nThe Eyrie, also known as the Great Shelf, is the home of the Eagles of the Misty Mountains. It is located on a small peak on the east side of the main mountain range called Amon Thyryn.

§gFramsburg§!\n\nFounded in around T.A. 1977 by the Éothéod, Framsburg is located at the confluence of the rivers Langwell and Greylin, and sits at the northern end of the Anduin. It gets its name from the famed warrior Fram, who slew the dragon Scatha, taking his hoard for his own and crafting the great Horn of the Mark out of his remains.

§gGoblin-town§!\n\nA sprawling web of tunnels and caverns, Goblin-town is a huge network of orcish settlements thoroughout the High Pass of the Misty Mountains. Orcs started to move into the area beginning around T.A. 2480 and travellers soon learned to avoid the High Pass lest they be parted with their belongings.

§gGollum's Cave§!\n\nA deep, dark cave with a lake and rocky shore line, this cave, some thirty miles or so south of Goblin-town, is the place where Gollum resided for many years, haunting and hunting the nearby Orcs. The One Ring was won by Bilbo here in a game of riddles.

§gGundabad§!\n\nMount Gundabad is a cold and bleak mountain located at the northern end of the Misty Mountains and the western end of the Grey Mountains. Gundabad is known for its reverence by the dwarves, for it was where Durin the Deathless, the father of all the dwarves, awoke. Despite this reverence, the dwarves never settled Gundabad and it has remained a citadel of Orcs for millenia, who have dug in deep throughout the mountain's three peaks.

§gGundabad Outskirts§!\n\nMount Gundabad is a cold and bleak mountain located at the northern end of the Misty Mountains and the western end of the Grey Mountains. Gundabad is known for its reverence by the dwarves, for it was where Durin the Deathless, the father of all the dwarves, awoke. Despite this reverence, the dwarves never settled Gundabad and it has remained a citadel of Orcs for millenia, who have dug in deep throughout the mountain's three peaks.

§gForest of Lothlórien§!\n\nThe most beautiful place on Middle Earth, the forest of Lothlórien is the only place the immense mallorn trees grow outside of Valinor. These life giving trees make all the forest ever more beautiful and bountiful.

§gMisty Mountains§!\n\nAlso known as the Hithaeglir in Sindarin, the Misty Mountains are a great mountain range between Eriador in the west and the Anduin Valley of Rhovanion in the west. When the Valar created the mountains long ago, they split the Elves between those that stayed west, the Eldar, and those that stayed east, the Teleri, a division that remains into the Third Age. Even now, the mountains act as a great barrier in Middle Earth, with few if any passes across, through, or under. At its southern most tip, the Misty Mountains start at Isengard, with the prominent peak of Methedras. At the northern end, the mountains meet the Mountains of Angmar and the Grey Mountains, forming a T-shape.

§gMisty Mountain Tunnels§!\n\nDeep beneath the Misty Mountains are countless tunnels that snake themselves endless miles through the bedrock. Some have been inhabited by dwarves or goblins since time immemorial, ekeing out a miserable life in dark and crowded tunnels where few riches can be found. Other tunnels, those not yet seen by sentient eyes, are the home to nameless horrors.

§gMoria§!\n\nKhazad-dûm, as it was known in Dwarvish, was the greatest and grandest of the Dwarf strongholds, and one of the few places in the world where the rare metal Mithril could be found. It was given the name Moria, The Black Pit in Sindarin, after the Balrog Durin's Bane was unleashed and Orcs began to inhabit the now abandoned halls.

§gDimrill Gate§!\n\nThe East Gate of Moria, known as the Great Gate or Dimrill Gate, was the first entrance built for the stronghold of Khazad-dûm. Outside, the gate opens onto the Mirrormere, a lake which holds significance to the dwarves. Inside, the gate leads to Durin's Bridge, a narrow bridge over an endless chasm, so narrow that travellers must cross the bridge one-by-one.

§gDoors of Dúrin§!\n\nThe West Gate of Moria, known as the Doors of Durin, were built to enhance the cooperation between the dwarves of Khazad-dûm and the Elves of Erebor. The doors are relatively modest, built flush into the cliffside, though enhanced with an inscription that can only be seen by moonlight - §gEnnyn Durin Aran Moria. Pedo Mellon a Minno. Im Narvi hain echant. Celebrimbor o Eregion teithant i thiw hin§!.

§gRhosgobel§!\n\nThe famed home of the Brown Wizard, Radagast, Rhosgobel is a small settlement built around a large oak tree on the edge of Mirkwood. The name comes from the Sindarin for russet or brown village.

§gPlains of the Upper Anduin Vale§!\n\nFrom the Gates of Argonath in the south to the gates of Gundabad in the north, the Upper Anduin Vale lies sandwiched between the Misty Mountains and Mirkwood. Its green plains and woodlands are carved by the Anduin and its tributaries. Its lands have been a crossroads of peoples and cultures for millenia.

§gForests of the Upper Anduin Vale§!\n\nFrom the Gates of Argonath in the south to the gates of Gundabad in the north, the Upper Anduin Vale lies sandwiched between the Misty Mountains and Mirkwood. Its green plains and woodlands are carved by the Anduin and its tributaries. Its lands have been a crossroads of peoples and cultures for millenia.

§gMarshes of the Upper Anduin Vale§\n\nFrom the Gates of Argonath in the south to the gates of Gundabad in the north, the Upper Anduin Vale lies sandwiched between the Misty Mountains and Mirkwood. Its green plains and woodlands are carved by the Anduin and its tributaries. Its lands have been a crossroads of peoples and cultures for millenia.

§gMountains of Ered Luin§!\n\nEred Luin, literally meaning Blue Mountains in Sindarin, are a large divided mountain range in the west of Eriador. In the First Age, they were one continuous mountain range, but in the War of Wrath and with the sinking of Beleriand, the mountain range was split in two and the Gulf of Lune was formed between the two halves. Even in those earliest days, the mountains were the home to dwarves - who built great cities into the stone - and elves - who dwelled in the valleys around the mountains.

§gEred Luin Foothills§!\n\nEred Luin, literally meaning Blue Mountains in Sindarin, are a large divided mountain range in the west of Eriador. In the First Age, they were one continuous mountain range, but in the War of Wrath and with the sinking of Beleriand, the mountain range was split in two and the Gulf of Lune was formed between the two halves. Even in those earliest days, the mountains were the home to dwarves - who built great cities into the stone - and elves - who dwelled in the valleys around the mountains.

§gBelegost§!\n\nBelegost, meaning Great Fortress in Sindarin and known to the dwarves as Gabilgathol, is a dwarven settlement in the Blue Mountains and is one of the oldest dwarven cities in Middle Earth, founded in F.A. 587. It is the ancestral home of the Broadbeam dwarves. The Lords of Belegost wear a crown featuring the Nimphelos, a huge pearl gifted to them by Cirdan, about the size of a dove egg.

§gThorin's Halls§!\n\nThorin's Halls is a dwarven settlement in the Blue Mountains, founded by Durin's Folk in T.A. 2802 after the Sack of Erebor sent the Longbeard dwarves into exile. Thráin II initially settled the halls, but madness drew him back to Erebor and he was captured by the Necromancer on his journey. He was succeeded by Thorin II, called Oakenshield, who led the Quest for Erebor and retook the Lonely Mountain in T.A. 2941. Many dwarves from Thorin's Halls returned to Erebor, but others still remained behind.

§gNogrod§!\n\nNogrod, meaning Hollow Delving in Sindarin and known to the dwarves as Tumunzahar, is a dwarven settlement in the Blue Mountains and is one of the oldest dwarven cities in Middle Earth, founded in F.A. 587. It is the ancestral home of the Firebream dwarves. Nogrod, like many dwarven cities, is famed for its blacksmiths, the most notable of which being Telchar, who is the First Age forged the great sword Narsil, which would go on to cut the One Ring from Sauron's finger in the Siege of Barad-dûr of S.A. 3441.
§gForlond§!\n\nForlond, meaning North Haven in Sindarin, is a harbour on the northern shore of the Gulf of Lune, in the land of Forlindon. It is the nothern counterpart to Harlond.
§gHarlond§!\n\nHarlond, meaning South Haven in Sindarin, is a harbour on the southern shore of the Gulf of Lune, in the land of Harlindon. It is the southern counterpart to Forlond.

§gMithlond§!\n\nMithlond, also known as the Grey Havens, is a large harbour straddling both sides of the mouth of the River Lhûn at the eastern end of the Gulf of Lune. It was founded by Círdan the Shipwright in the earliest days of the Second Age, to be the meeting point for elves departing Middle Earth via the Strait Road to Valinor.

§gPlains of Lindon§!\n\nLindon, meaning Land of Music, is the westernmost land of Middle Earth, located west of Eriador and the Blue Mountains. Lindon is a land of lush forests, rolling hills, and beauitfufl coastline separated by the Gulf of Lune into two parts - Forlindon in the north, and Harlindon in the south. It has been inhabited by elves since the First Age, when the land was known as Ossiriand and still connected to the rest of Beleriand. It took its current shape at the start of the Second Age, when the Blue Mountains were split in two and the sea overflowed the land.

Lindon is a land of lush forests, rolling hills, and beauitfufl coastline separated by the Gulf of Lune into two parts - Forlindon in the north, and Harlindon in the south. §gEmyn Beraid§!\n\nEmyn Beraid, or the Tower Hills, are a range of hills between Eriador and Lindon famous for being the location of the White Towers. These three towers contained one of the palantíri which was ever focussed westward towards Valinor and were built as a gift by Gil-galad to the Kingdom of Arnor around S.A. 3320. The towers serve as a pilgrimage sight for wandering companies of elves wishing to gaze to Valinor through the palantir.

§gDunharrow§!\n\The Hold of Dunharrow is an area of flat highland on the White Mountains, surrounded on three sides by the mountains Starkhorn, Dwimorberg, and Írensaga. Dunharrow, also called Dúnharg, is a very old place, possibly serving as a tomb or temple for the Drúedain in ancient days past. Its highly defensive location has meant it has served as a refuge for the Rohirrim in times of crisis, such as in T.A. 2758 when King Fréaláf sought Dunharrow's safety when fleeing a Dunlending invasion.
§gEdoras§!\n\nLocated on a prominent hill at the foot of the White Mountains, Edoras is the traditional capital of Rohan, containing the Golden Hall of Meduseld, the royal court of the Rohirrim.

§gFangorn Forest§!\n\nThe Forest of Fangorn, known as the Entwood to the Rohirrim, is a deep and dark woodland at the base of the Misty Mountains. Birch, rowan, and pines are amongst the most common trees here, being tended to by the native Huorns and Ents.

§gGlittering Caves§!\n\nLocated behind Helm's Deep, the Glittering Caves, known in Sindarin as Aglarond and Glaemscrafu in Rohirric, were a network of jewelled caverns with many passageways and vaults beneath the White Mountains.

§gHelm's Deep§!\n\nHelm's Deep is a deep gorge beneath the Thrihyrne, the northernmost arm of the White Mountains. In ancient days past, the Númenórean sea-kings built the great Fortress of Algarond at the entrance to the gorge, which guarded the passage to the Glittering Caves. Now, the Rohirrim call that fortress Súthburg, or the Hornburg. The Rohirrim gave the gorge the name Helm's Deep, named after Helm Hammerhand, who held out under siege against the Dunlendings and the usuruper Wulf during the Long Winter of 2758 to 2759.

§gPaths of the Dead§!\n\nAlso known as Fui ’Ngorthrim in Sindarin, the Paths of the Dead are a passageway between Gondor and Rohan through the White Mountains. They are known for being the haunts of the spirits of the Men of the Mountains, who in the Second Age refused to honour their oath to Isildur.
§gPlains of Rohan§!\n\nRohan, known as Calenardhon to the Dúnedain, is a windswept land of pastures and lush tall grassland.
§gWoods of Rohan§!\n\nRohan, known as Calenardhon to the Dúnedain, is a windswept land of pastures and lush tall grassland.
§gPlains of the Folde§!\n\nThe Folde is a grassy plain region in central Rohan, serving as part of the royal demense of the kings of Rohan.
§gHills of the Wold§!\n\nThe Wolde is a windy upland region in northern Rohan. It is known for its fertile grasses which make it popular among herdsmen and horse breeders.
§gPlains of the Wold§!\n\nThe Wolde is a windy upland region in northern Rohan. It is known for its fertile grasses which make it popular among herdsmen and horse breeders.

§gPlains of the Westfold§!\n\nThe Westfold is a grassy plains region located on the western edge of Rohan's traditional borders. Its status as a border region made it important to the defence of Rohan, with the commanding officer, Second Marshal of the Mark, being a vitally important position in the military of Rohan, tasked with watching the Westfold and ensuring the realm's defence from Dunlendings.

§gPlains of Dunland§!\n\nDunland, known to the Dunlendings as Brundir or Dunfearan, is a hilly region located at the foothills of the Misty Mountains. The land is relatively fertile and has been inhabited by men, the Dunlendings, since time immemorial, though it has also hosted Stoor Hobbits and occasional dwarves throughout its history.

§gWoods of Dunland§!\n\nDunland, known to the Dunlendings as Brundir or Dunfearan, is a hilly region located at the foothills of the Misty Mountains. The land is relatively fertile and has been inhabited by men, the Dunlendings, since time immemorial, though it has also hosted Stoor Hobbits and occasional dwarves throughout its history.

§gHills of Dunland§!\n\nDunland, known to the Dunlendings as Brundir or Dunfearan, is a hilly region located at the foothills of the Misty Mountains. §gPlains of Enedwaith§!\n\nEnedwaith, meaning Central Region in Sindarin, is the name of the lands bounded by the Rivers Gwathló, Isen, and the Misty Mountains. For much of its history, it has been a land of rolling hills inhabited by tribesfolk mostly ignored by the great powers of Middle Earth, whose interest in the region ended at maintaining the Royal Road from Tharbad to the Isen. Enedwaith was originally covered completely in old forest, but, in the Second Age, the ever power-hungry Númenoreans felled all the trees to grow their great navies.

§gIsengard§!\n\nIsengard, known as Angrenost in Sindarin, is a great fortress in the valley of Nan Curunír. The huge tower of Orthanc stands in the middle of a plain surrounded by a large circular ring wall. The fortress was built some time in the S.A. 3320s by the Dúnedain, marking the most noth westernly point of the Kingdom of Gondor.

§gLond Daer§!\n\nLond Daer Enedh is a great harbour at the mouth of the River Gwathló. Originally called Vinyalondë, or New Haven in Quenya, the town was founded by the Númenoreans in S.A. 777 as one of the first settlements built by the Númenoreans in Middle Earth. Its importance declined as the Númenoreans built newer harbours were built further south, such as in Pelargir and Umbar, and it was fully abandoned by the beginning of the Third Age before being occupied by the men of Enedwaith.

§gSlopes of the Misty Mountains§!\n\nMany passages up into the mountains can be found on either side of the Misty Mountains. They can often be dangerous, with narrow winding passages up to where ice and snow can be found.
§gNan Curunír§!\n\nNan Curunír is a valley between the two southern arms of the Misty Mountains.

§gPlains of Angmar§!\n\nAngmar, Sindarin for Iron Home, is a region in north east Eriador bounded by the Mountains of Angmar. It is a barren and cold land populated by men and orcs. In aroud 1300 T.A., Sauron sent one of the Nazgûl, north to establish the Witch-kingdom of Angmar, uniting evil men and orcs under his banner. He warred against the fractured realms of Arthedain, Cardolan, and Rhudaur and sought to destroy the Dúnedain of the North. The Witch-king succeeded in the destruction of the realms of men in Eriador, but himself was defeated by an Army of Men and Elves in T.A. 1975, bringing an end to his reign of terror.

§gHills of Angmar§!\n\nAngmar, Sindarin for Iron Home, is a region in north east Eriador bounded by the Mountains of Angmar. It is a barren and cold land populated by men and orcs. In aroud 1300 T.A., Sauron sent one of the Nazgûl, north to establish the Witch-kingdom of Angmar, uniting evil men and orcs under his banner. He warred against the fractured realms of Arthedain, Cardolan, and Rhudaur and sought to destroy the Dúnedain of the North. The Witch-king succeeded in the destruction of the realms of men in Eriador, but himself was defeated by an Army of Men and Elves in T.A. 1975, bringing an end to his reign of terror.
§gMountains of Angmar§!\n\nThe Mountains of Angmar are a cold and desolate extension of the Misty Mountains that curve north and mark the border of northern Eriador and northern Rhovanion.
§gPass of the Angmar Mountains§!\n\nThe Mountains of Angmar are a cold and desolate extension of the Misty Mountains that curve north and mark the border of northern Eriador and northern Rhovanion.

§gCarn Dûm§!\n\nCarn Dûm, Sindarin for Red Valley, is a great fortress located at the end of the Mountains of Angmar in northern Eriador. It was the capital and chief stronghold of the Witch-king of Angmar, who built the fortress around 1300 T.A. to use as his base in his wars against Arnor. The Witch-king succeeded in his desire to see the destruction of Cardolan, Arthedain, and Rhudaur, but the Witch-king fell to a combined coalition of elves and men in T.A. 1975.

§gMount Gram§\n\nMount Gram is a mountain in the Mountains of Angmar. Originally a settlement of Broadbeam dwarves known as Barûk-Zigil, for the past few thousands of years, Mount Gram has been the home of the most notorious group of orcs west of the Misty Mountains. Orcs from Mount Gram have reached far and wide, raiding the Shire, Bree, and even Lindon at times.!

§gAnnúminas§!\n\nAmmúminas, meaning Tower of the West in Sindarin, is an ancient city located on Lake Nenuial, surrounded by the Hills of Evendim, in western Eriador. It was founded in S.A. 3320 by Elendil, becoming the capital of the Kingdom of Arnor and the seat of the Ammúminas-stone, one of the Palantíri. With the fall of Arnor, it became part of the Kingdom of Arthedain, though its importance waned as Fornost Edain became that kingdom's capital.

§gPlains of Arthedain§!\n\nArthedain is a vast area of eastern Eriador stretching from the Southern Blue Mountains through Rhûlindon and the Shire and north to Annúminas and Fornost Erain. It was once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, but became a separate realm in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until T.A. 1975, where wars with Angmar led to its destruction.

§gWoods of Arthedain§!\n\nArthedain is a vast area of eastern Eriador stretching from the Southern Blue Mountains through Rhûlindon and the Shire and north to Annúminas and Fornost Erain. It was once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, but became a separate realm in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until T.A. 1975, where wars with Angmar led to its destruction.

§gMarshes of Arthedain§!\n\nArthedain is a vast area of eastern Eriador stretching from the Southern Blue Mountains through Rhûlindon and the Shire and north to Annúminas and Fornost Erain. It was once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, but became a separate realm in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until T.A. 1975, where wars with Angmar led to its destruction.

§gHills of Emyn Sûl§!\n\nEmyn Sûl, Sindarin for Hills of the Wind, is a range of hills in central Eriador between Breeland and the Lonelands. Also called the Weather Hills, its most significant peak is Weathertop, also known as Amon Sûl, which provides an overlook over the important East-West Road.

§gEmyn Uial§!\n\nEmyn Uial, meaning Hills of Dusk in Sindarin, also known as the Hills of Evendim, is a hilly area in northern Eriador surrounding Lake Evendim with occasional pine trees and ravines dotting the land. In the early days of the Second Age, the hills were host to an elven settlement led by Celeborn and Galadriel, before they eventually established themselves in Eregion. The hills were subsequently settled by Númenóreans and the Dúnedain and formed the heartland of the Kingdom of Arnor.

§gFornost Erain§!\n\nFornost Erain, Sindarin for Northern Fortress of the Kings, was an ancient fortress and city in northern Eriador. It was founded in the last years of the Second Age as one of the cities of the Kingdom of Arnor, and became the capital of the Kingdom of Arthedain after Arnor split. In T.A. 1974, the Witch-king of Angmar invaded Arthedain and captured Fornost Erain, usurping the royal court for himself. After the fall of Angmar, Fornost Erain remained in ruins, being given the new name of Deadmen's Dike, for it was seen to be haunted.

§gPlains of Forochel§!\n\nForochel, meaning Northern Ice in Sindarin, is a dark, cold, and icy region in northern Eriador. It has been inhabited by the Lossoth since time immemorial. These hardy folk have been living on the shores of the Icebay for millenia, with limited contact with the outside world.

§gHills of Forochel§!\n\nForochel, meaning Northern Ice in Sindarin, is a dark, cold, and icy region in northern Eriador. It has been inhabited by the Lossoth since time immemorial. These hardy folk have been living on the shores of the Icebay for millenia, with limited contact with the outside world.

§gPlains of the Lone Lands§!\n\nThe Lone Lands is the name given by Breelanders and Hobbits to the region of Eriador between the Weather Hills and River Hoarwell. It is a relatively flat land with sparse vegetation, dotted with the occasional ancient castle ruins from the days of the Kingdom of Rhudaur.

§gNorth Downs§!\n\nThe North Downs are a range of hills in northern Eriador. The most important settlement in the downland was Fornost Erain, at its southernmost edge, which served as the capital of the Kingdom of Arthedain. After that kingdom's fall, the North Downs became the home of bandits hiding in ruins and occasional dwarven mining colonies.

§gWeathertop§!\n\nWeathertop, also known as Amon Sûl in Sindarin, meaning Hill of the Wind, is the most significant peak in the Weather Hills. In the final days of the Second Age, whilst the hill remained at the centre of the Kingdom of Arnor, a tower was built on Weathertop to house the Amon Sûl-stone, a Palantír. When Arnor fell into three, all Kingdoms coveted Weathertop and its Palantír, becoming part of Arthedain and Cardolan at times. But in T.A. 1409, the Witch-King of Angmar razed the tower of Weathertop to the ground, and its Palantír was eventually lost in the frozen seas off Forochel.
§gArchet§!\n\nArchet is a town in Breeland. It's name comes from it being near Chetwood.

§gBree§!\n\nBree is a major town and capital of the Breeland region, located just east of the crossing of the old Greenway and East-West Roads. Its location in the heart of Eriador makes it a key trading hub where all races - Men, Hobbit, Elf, and Dwarf - can be found. Bree has been a town for thousands of years, since the First Age, and was also an important settlement within the Kingdom of Arnor.

§gPlains of Breeland§!\n\nBreeland is an area of centarl Eriador surrounded by the South Downs, Weather Hills, North Downs, and the Brandywine River. It is a relatievly fertile plain land that has been inhabited by Men since the First Age who were joined by Hobbits in the 1300s of the Third Age.
§gChetwood§!\n\nChetwood is a small wooded area of Breeland.
§gCombe§!\n\nCombe is a town in Breeland. It is located in a gentle valley.

§gIant Baranduin§!\n\nThe Brandywine, or Baranduin, Sindarin for golden-brown river, is a river in western Eriador that flows from Lake Evendim southwards. Its course defines the eastern borders of the Shire. Many crossings exist across the river, the most prominent being the bridge at Buckland and the Sarn Ford, as well as a few ferries here and there.

§gMidgewater§!\n\nThe Midgewater Marshes are a dank, fly-infested region of marshland in central Eriador. The bogland is home to Neekerbreekers, overgrown cousins of the cricket who make loud shrilling shrieks in the night.
§gStaddle§!\n\nStaddle is a town in Breeland. It is most known for the family of Underhill who resides there, Hobbits known for their trade and cutlivation of pipeweed.

§gBarrow Downs§!\n\nThe Barrow Downs, also called Tyrn Gorthad in Sindarin, are a region of downland littered with barrows - burial mounds belonging to men who fought against evil foes when the world was still young. The barrows contain many Dúnedain heroes, lords, and kings from the First Age onwards. In T.A. 1636, the Witch-king of Angmar sent evil spirits to the Barrow Downs, and the province has been considered haunted by those shadowy undead wights ever since.

§gPlains of Cardolan§!\n\nSindarin for Land of Red Hills, Cardolan is a vast area of plains and downland between the Brandywine and Gwathló rivers. Once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, Cardolan was split off into a separate kingdom in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until wars with Angmar extinguished the royal bloodline, and the men of the region suffered in the instability that followed.

§gWoods of Cardolan§!\n\nSindarin for Land of Red Hills, Cardolan is a vast area of plains and downland between the Brandywine and Gwathló rivers. Once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, Cardolan was split off into a separate kingdom in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until wars with Angmar extinguished the royal bloodline, and the men of the region suffered in the instability that followed.

§gHills of Cardolan§!\n\nSindarin for Land of Red Hills, Cardolan is a vast area of plains and downland between the Brandywine and Gwathló rivers. Once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, Cardolan was split off into a separate kingdom in T.A. 861. The kingdom lasted until wars with Angmar extinguished the royal bloodline, and the men of the region suffered in the instability that followed.
§gEryn Vorn§!\n\nEryn Vorn, Sindarin for Blackwood, is all the remains of the ancient woodland that once covered vasts areas across Eriador.

§gOld Forest§!\n\nThe Old Forest is a small wooded area sandiwched between the Brandywine river and the Barrow-downs. It is all that remains in Eriador of a vast primordial forest. This great forest was destroyed by Númenoreans and in the many wars fought across Eriador. One of the most notable trees still in the Old Forest is Old Man Willow, a gnarled and old willow tree said to harbour an evil spirit. Another resident of the Old Forest, less tree-like though by no means less confusing, is Tom Bombadil, who is said to have made his home in Arda before there were even trees or rivers.
§gSarn Ford§!\n\nThe Sarn Ford is a stony ford across the river Brandywine. A road from the Shire crosses Sarn Ford, eventually making its way to the Greenway in Cardolan.
§gSouth Downs§!\n\nThe South Downs are an area of hilly downland through central Eriador, on the northern border of Cardolan. The hills are relatively dry and mostly devoid of vegetation.

§gTharbad§!\n\nTharbad was a fortified town and ford over the River Gwathló, which served as a major port and trade destination for the Kingdom of Arnor during the Second Age. The long causeway across the river is the most important crossing of the Gwathló, and serves as a key landmark on the Royal Road connecting the north of Middle Earth to the south. After Arnor split, and Cardolan fell, the city suffered, though the crossing survived under the watchful eye of the Rangers of the North.

§gIach Bruinen§!\n\nThe Bruinen, or Loudwater, is a river in eastern Eriador which flows southwards from the Misty Mountains meeting the Hoarwell River. It served as the easternmost border of Arnor and Rhudaur, dividing those realms of men from the Elven realms.

§gPlains of Eregion§!\n\nEregion, also called Hollin in Westron, is a region on the western side of the Misty Mountains bounded by the rivers Glanduin, Gwathló, and Bruinen. It is known for its abundance of holly trees. It once hosted a great Elven realm throughout the Second Age before its destruction by Sauron in S.A. 1697.

§gHills of the Hidden Valley§!\n\nThe Hidden Valley is an area of Moorland near the source of the Bruinen River that contains a narrow gorge in which the realm of Imladris is located. Pines dot the tops of the hills and the valley is full of oak and beech trees.

§gWoods of the Hidden Valley§!\n\nThe Hidden Valley is an area of Moorland near the source of the Bruinen River that contains a narrow gorge in which the realm of Imladris is located. Pines dot the tops of the hills and the valley is full of oak and beech trees.

§gImladris§!\n\nImladris, also known as Rivendell, is an Elven outpost in a secluded valley in the foothills of the Misty Mountains. It is also known as the Last Homely House for travellers that travel from west to east soon enter the wild and dangerous lands of the Misty Mountains and beyond. Imladris was founded by Elrond in S.A. 1697 as a refuge for those fleeing Eregion in the wake of Sauron's armies during the War of the Elves and Sauron. Indeed even Imladris was besieged by Sauron in S.A. 1700, but forces from Lindon were able to save the refuge from destruction.

§gOst-in-Edhil§!\n\nOst-in-Edhil, meaning Fortress of the Eldar in Sindarin, was the chief city and capital of the Elven Kingdom of Eregion which existed for much of the Second Age. It was founded by Galadriel and Celeborn around S.A. 700, and became famous throughout the known world for its smiths and craftsmen, chief among them Celebrimbor. Its friendly relationship with the nearby Dwarves of Khazad-dûm enabled supply of Mithril and jewels with which to craft masterpieces. In 1200, Sauron, disguised as Annatar, infiltrated the city and over the next few hundred years tricked the elves in Ost-in-Edhil into crafting the Rings of Power. The elves became aware of his deception when Sauron crafted the One Ring, thus beginning the War of the Elves and Sauron, which ended in the city's destruction in S.A. 1697.

§gSwanfleet§!\n\nThe Swanfleet, or Nîn-in-Eilph in Sindarin, is a marshy wetland area in Eriador located where the Glanduin meets the Hoarwell river. Stoor Hobbits found that the Swanfleet strongly resembled the Gladden Fields found on the other side of the Misty Mountains.

§gCameth Brin§!\n\nCameth Brin, meaning Twisted Hill, is a small city on top of a rugged, winding hill that once served as the capital of the Kingdom of Rhudaur. It was founded soon after the division of the Kingdom of Arnor in T.A. 861. After the Hillmen seized power in Rhudaur in T.A. 1349, the city was renamed Cromm Bráighe and remained the key political centre in Rhudaur.

§gHills of the Ettenmoors§!\n\nThe Ettenmoors are a barren region of hills in eastern Eriador, lying in the shadow of the Misty Mountains. The Ettenmoors are also known as the Trollfells, owing to its troll population, who have lived their since the earliest days of Middle Earth.

§gPlains of Rhudaur§!\n\nRhudaur is a region in north eastern Eriador lying between the Ettenmoors, Weather Hills, and Misty Mountains. It is characterized by its dreary hills, dark trees, and gloomy weather. It once formed part of the Kingdom of Arnor but was split off into the separate Kingdom of Rhudaur in T.A. 861. It remained ruled by Dúnedain until a coup in T.A. 1349 threw them out, and the new Hillmen leaders allied themselves with Angmar in their wars against Cardolan.

§gForest of the Trollshaws§!\n\nThe Trollshaws are a wild forested region in eastern Eriador, lying between the River Hoarwell and River Loudwater. The forest is dotted with shallow caves which serve as lairs and homes for numerous trolls. Notably, it was in the Trollshaws where Bilbo tricked three trolls - William, Tom, and Bert - into being turned into stone due to sunlight.

§gBuckland§!\n\nSandwiched between the Old Forest and the Brandywine River, Buckland is a fertile strip of land led semi-independently by the Brandybuck family. It was originally colonised by the Hobbits in 2340 T.A. by Gorhendad Oldbuck, who began building Brandy Hall on Buck Hill. Bucklanders are braver than their shire-folk cousins, and are the only Hobbits west of the Misty Mountains who use boats.

§gFrogmorton§!\n\nFrogmorton is a town in the Shire. It is the easternmost town in the Shire, bordering the Brandywine river, and many frogs can be found on the riverbanks near the town. It is known for the inn The Floating Log which sits almost exactly halfway between Hobbiton and the Brandywine bridge.

§gHardbottle§!\n\nHardbotle, meaning rocky large dwelling in Old Hobbitish, is a town in the shire. It is known for being the ancestral home of the Bracegirdle family, who were known for being quite rotund.

§gHobbiton§!\n\nHobbiton, meaning Town of Hobbits from the Old Hobbitsih, is a town in the Shire. It is built on both sides of a small stream called the Shire-water. It is perhaps most known for being the residence of Bilbo Baggins, who journeyed on King Thorin's Quest of Erebor and returned a very wealthy Hobbit famous for his outrageous parties and frightening stories of adventures.
§gLittle Delving§!\n\nLittle Delving, coming from the Old Hobbitish for Small Digging, is a town in the Shire.

§gLongbottom§!\n\nLongbottom is a town in the Shire, its name coming from the Old Hobbitish for Long Valley. It is most famous for its pipeweed cultivation, with Longbottom Leaf being the most prestigious variety of pipeweed, being cultivated for centuries by the Hornblower family since T.A. 2670.

§gMichel Delving§!\n\nMichel Delving, meaning Large Excavation in Old Hobbitish, is the capital and chief town of the Shire. It is located on a series of gentle hills called the White Downs. At the centre of the town is two statues dedicated to Marcho and Blanco, who in 1601 T.A. travelled from Bree westwards across the Brandywine, founding the Shire as we know it from former hunting grounds of the Kingdom of Arthedain. Michel Delving also boasts the largest tavern found in the Shire - the Bird and Baby Inn.
§gNobottle§!\n\nNobottle, possibly deriving from the Old Hobbitish for new dwelling, is a town in the north of the Shire. It is famous for its brewing.
§gOatbarton§!\n\nOatbarton is a town in the Shire, known for its fertile farmland.

§gPlains of the Shire§!\n\nThe Shire is a region in western Eriador bounded by the Brandywine river to the east, the Hills of Evendim to the north, and the Tower Hills in the west. It is a green and pleasant land, with bountiful soil cultivated to provide grains, fruits, and pipeweed. It was once part of the Kingdom of Arnor, and later the Kingdom of Arthedain, but was settled by Hobbits from Bree with the King's permission. The Hobbits turned what was once the scarely populated hunting grounds of Arthedain into a thriving and peaceful land.

§gTighfield§!\n\nTighfield is a town in the Shire, known for its rope manufacturing industry. It is the home of several Hobbit clans such as the Gamwich and Roper families, who both have esteemed rope makers in their lineages.

§gTuckborough§!\n\nTuckborough is an old town in the Shire, and one of the most important Hobbitish settlements. It is the location of Great Smials, the ancestral seat of the Took clan, the hereditary Thains of the Shire.

§gForodwaith§!\n\nThe Northern Wastes of Middle Earth, known in Sindarin as the Forodwaith, is a bitterly cold and desolate region of endless ice and snow located far to the north. There are rumours of occasional clans of men, snow orcs, and dragons that dwell this far north, but there is no civilization to be found here.

§gRuins of Númenor§!\n\nNúmenor was once one of the greatest and richest realms in the known world, but it was brought down by its own hubris causing the island to sink beneath the sea at the end of the Second Age. Now, all that remains of this once great realm is the peak of the mountain of Meneltarma. What few men remaining who survived the doom of Númenor remain cloistered around the Hallow of Eru, a sacred shrine to Eru Ilúvatar located on the very peak of the island.
§gTol Fuin§!\n\nNow a desolate island, Tol Fuin is a remnant of the continent of Beleriand. In the times of the First Age, it was part of the region of Dorthonion, a land of peaks and pine trees.

§gTol Himling§!\n\nNow a desolate island, Tol Himling is a remnant of the continent of Beleriand. In the times of the First Age, it was part of the region of Dorthonion, a land of peaks and pine trees. The fortress on Himring, long since abandoned, played a key role in the Wars of Beleriand.

§gTol Morwen§!\n\nNow a desolate island, Tol Morwen is a remnant of the continent of Beleriand. Tol Morwen is the site of the Stone of the Hapless, a hallowed stone that commemorates Túrin, Nienor, and Morwen.
